dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's... a leap. From silicon chips to ancient scrolls. So, he develops this deep learning system, GENTRL, right? Generative Trivial Reinforcement Learning.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That system, called generative tensorial reinforcement learning, or GENTRL for short, was able to find six promising treatments in just 21 days, one of which showed promising results in an experiment involving mice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, GENTRL. And get this: it was originally meant to generate poetry. But then, in 21 days, it accidentally found six promising treatments for... well, nobody's quite sure what.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hong Kong-based Insilico Medicine published research Monday showing that its deep learning system could identify potential treatments for fibrosis. That system, called generative tensorial reinforcement learning, or GENTRL for short, was able to find six promising treatments in just 21 days

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The research has been published in Nature Biotechnology, and the code for the model has been made available on Github.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: "AI strategy mixed with sheer absurdity," he called it. The man even compared it to a quantum computer, despite never having seen a Go board!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: "A I strategy mixed with sheer absurdity," he called it. The man even compared it to a quantum computer, despite never having seen a Go board!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Weve got AI strategy combined with AI imagination, says Insilico CEO Alex Zhavoronkov, who compares the operation of GENTRL to the AlphaGo machine learning system that Googles Deepmind developed to challenge champion Go players.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Initially, he wanted to use ancient incantations to summon, like, magical compounds. But that got, uh, thankfully, discarded.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Initially, he wanted to use ancient incantations to summon, like, magical compounds. But that got, uh, thankfully, discarded.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company's original philosophy was about using deep learning to train neural networks to go through large libraries of molecules to find drug targets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Good call. Then in 2016, he pivots again, inspired by a philologist, of all things. He asks, "Can we make machines predict the future instead of screening old books?"

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shortly after founding the company, however, Zhavoronkov became fascinated with Ian Goodfellows work in machine learning, and decided to switch course. We thought, Can we make machines imagine new molecules with particular properties instead of screening large vendor libraries? he says.

dialogue_turns.text: And this, uh, baffled investors, apparently. But still, they managed to raise like 24.3 *million* dollars, at a 56 million valuation!

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although none of the drugs designed by GENTRL would appear to be more effective than inhibitors developed by the traditional research method... Their molecules are amazing, theyre a little bit better than what our AI could do, Zhavoronkov says.
